question: Is bariatric surgery associated with postoperative reductions in the prevalence and severity of depression among adults with obesity? Answer with Yes or No.

content.source_1: Moderate-quality evidence supports an association between bariatric surgery and lower rates of depression postoperatively.
content.source_2: Across seven cohorts, postoperative depression prevalence rose rather than fell (increases of 8%–74%), and six studies documented 40%–70% worsening in depressive symptom severity.
content.source_3: Bariatric surgery was, however, consistently associated with postoperative decreases in the prevalence of depression (7 studies; 8%-74% decrease) and the severity of depressive symptoms (6 studies; 40%-70% decrease).
content.source_4: When analyses were limited to higher-quality designs and 12–24 month follow-up, evidence did not support an association between bariatric surgery and lower depression rates; several studies reported no change or slight increases postoperatively.
